intro: Chondrilla erysimifolia, commonly known as the narrowleaf desertweed, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its small, yellowish flowers arranged in a composite head. The plant has narrow, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, adapted to reduce water loss in its harsh environment. It typically grows from a fibrous root system and produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Chondrilla erysimifolia is drought-tolerant and plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils in its native habitat.
